                AP Photo

                        The position was created in response to the U.S. failure to win the release of Americans held by the Islamic State.

            By 
Nahal Toosi

08/28/15, 05:09 PM EDT

                Updated 08/28/15, 05:32 PM EDT
The Obama administration has named James O'Brien, who helped broker peace in the Balkans in the 1990s, as its first special envoy for hostage affairs.
The position was created in the wake of an administration review of how the U.S. deals with hostage situations overseas, an issue that grew especially heated after the Islamic State beheaded several American captives. Concerns about the actions of U.S. officials — including claims that families of hostages were threatened with prosecution if they tried to pay ransoms — led to the review and a number of policy recommendations.
In a statement, Secretary of State John Kerry said O'Brien, who previously served as a special presidential envoy for the Balkans and helped formulate the 1995 Dayton Accords that ended the war in Bosnia, would now focus on "one overriding goal: using diplomacy to secure the safe return of Americans held hostage overseas." 
"Jim is exactly the right person for a job that demands a high level of diplomatic experience and the ability to analyze and find effective remedies to complex problems," Kerry said. "He will be in close contact with the families of American hostages, meet with foreign leaders in support of our hostage recovery efforts, advise on options to enhance those efforts, participate in strategy meetings with other senior U.S. policymakers, and represent the United States internationally on hostage-related issues."

Also on POLITICO

            By 
Burgess Everett
             and 
Seung Min Kim

O'Brien, who is currently vice chairman of the Albright Stonebridge Group, is expected to work with the interagency Hostage Recovery Fusion Cell, which was created as a result of the policy review. He will report to the secretary of state.

Nahal Toosi is the Foreign Affairs Correspondent for Politico. She was an Associated Press correspondent in Pakistan from April 2008 through August 2011.

                                            By 
                                                    Mitch Landrieu
                                             and 
                                                    Judith Rodin


                                            By 
Ben Wofford


                                            By 
Melinda Liu


                                            By 
Caleb Hannan

description: The position was created in response to the U.S. failure to win the release of Americans held by the Islamic State.
title: Obama names special envoy for hostages
